etymologies: Middle English (in an earlier sense). Probably from early Scandinavian from a variant (without i-mutation) of the Scandinavian base of Old Icelandic reykr smoke, vapour, Old Swedish röker smoke, vapour, odour (Swedish rök), Old Danish røk smoke (Danish røg smoke, incense). Compare Anglo-Norman roke mist, fog

definitions: Steam; vapour, mist, fog, or an instance of this.

etymologies: mid 19th century; earliest use found in British Patents. Origin uncertain. Perhaps compare English regional (north.) roke, rawk, rawk flaw or defect in a piece of cloth, stone, metal, etc

definitions: A longitudinal surface defect in a steel ingot in the form of a thin shallow depression typically lined with scale.
